content: So six of eight slash commands change the local client rendering, if it's the only thing you send, and the other two do something special to your message rendering? That's an interesting dichotomy.
Of those 6, it's two sets of 4 and 2 equivalent commands, effectively.
I'm really not clear why the local client rendering options are slash commands, and not left as preferences.
I don't think that matches with most folks' expectations for what the message compose box is for.

Alex Dehnert said:

So six of eight slash commands change the local client rendering, if it's the only thing you send, and the other two do something special to your message rendering? That's an interesting dichotomy.

It's a totally strange dichotomy. Our slash commands are all over the map. It's the nature of slash commands. We have a really small sample size (four of the commands are all basically doing the same task).
I think we're fine with most everyone changing the client rendering options throught the menus. Does it cause any problems/confusion to have those slash commands available as well?

I think it buries the few composition items. And, I think our threshold for including something in there should be higher than "doesn't cause problems/confusion" -- I think nobody will look for UI setting in a slash command, particularly when they're also found elsewhere. For example, I don't think anyone would support putting /next in there as a n hotkey equivalent, despite it probably not causing problems/confusion. :smile:

That's fair... When I've asked Tim Abbott about why those commands are there (I did wonder when I first discovered it!), the motivation he gave (if I recall correctly) was that some users want to switch between day and night mode on a daily basis, and this makes it much more handy for them. Not sure how common that use case is.
Probably not common at all. :grinning:
Part of the history of slash commands is that we wanted to demonstrate the capabilities and certain developer(s) named Steve invented contrived use cases,
/me only takes partial blame

Yeah, I'd say that slash commands are generally not a super baked feature in Zulip. I consider it to be an unstable part of the product that is useful. (E.g. there's a good chance that /poll will eventually become a <poll> markdown widget someday).

I use the day/night slash commands a decent amount, but only for testing UI works in both themes :smile:
